coredata.dc:title: N-doped ordered mesoporous carbon (N-OMC) confined Fe3O4-FeCx heterojunction for efficient conversion of CO2 to light olefins
coredata.dc:creator: Zhang, Pengze
Han, Fei
Yan, Jingyu
Qiao, Xianliang
Guan, Qingxin
Li, Wei
coredata.dc:description: Converting CO2 into light olefins is full of challenges and opportunities, which was limited by poor activity catalysts. Herein, Fe3O4-FeCx heterojunction active site confined in N-doped graphene shell was synthesized on the surface of N-OMC. Alkali metal and N atom was used for modifying the surface electron density, which could suppress the excessive hydrogenation of CHx and improve the adsorption of CO2, thus increasing the yield of light olefins. The 0.8Fe-0.1K@N-OMC showed CO2 conversion of 54.5%, C2 =–C4 = selectivity of 65.63%, and a stability of 100 h (3.0 MPa, 320 °C, and GHSV = 4800 mL/gcat/h). The reaction mechanism was investigated using various characterization techniques, which demonstrates that the excellent catalytic active was originated from Fe3O4-FeCx heterojunction. The CO was first produced by the RWGS reaction catalyzed by Fe3O4, and then converted to light olefins on the neighboring FeCx active site by FTs reaction. Confinement effect of N-doped graphene shell inhibits the reoxidation and agglomeration of heterojunction active components, which boosts the catalyst' stability. This work proposes a simple and feasible synthesis strategy to construct Fe3O4-FeCx heterojunction catalysts, which provides insights into catalysts design and the reaction mechanism of CO2 conversion to light olefins.

head.ce:title: N-doped ordered mesoporous carbon (N-OMC) confined Fe3O4-FeCx heterojunction for efficient conversion of CO2 to light olefins

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: State Key Laboratory of Elemento-Organic Chemistry, Key Laboratory of Advanced Energy Materials Chemistry (Ministry of Education), College of Chemistry, Nankai University, No. 94 Weijin Road, Tianjin, 300071, PR China

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Fe3O4-FeCx heterojunction active site confined in N-OMC was prepared and showed excellent activity in converting CO2 to light olefins, which was attributed to the synergistic effect of heterojunction components in RWGS–FTS reaction.

Converting CO2 into light olefins is full of challenges and opportunities, which was limited by poor activity catalysts. Herein, Fe3O4-FeCx heterojunction active site confined in N-doped graphene shell was synthesized on the surface of N-OMC. Alkali metal and N atom was used for modifying the surface electron density, which could suppress the excessive hydrogenation of CHx and improve the adsorption of CO2, thus increasing the yield of light olefins. The 0.8Fe-0.1K@N-OMC showed CO2 conversion of 54.5%, C2 =–C4 = selectivity of 65.63%, and a stability of 100 h (3.0 MPa, 320 °C, and GHSV = 4800 mL/gcat/h). The reaction mechanism was investigated using various characterization techniques, which demonstrates that the excellent catalytic active was originated from Fe3O4-FeCx heterojunction. The CO was first produced by the RWGS reaction catalyzed by Fe3O4, and then converted to light olefins on the neighboring FeCx active site by FTs reaction. Confinement effect of N-doped graphene shell inhibits the reoxidation and agglomeration of heterojunction active components, which boosts the catalyst' stability. This work proposes a simple and feasible synthesis strategy to construct Fe3O4-FeCx heterojunction catalysts, which provides insights into catalysts design and the reaction mechanism of CO2 conversion to light olefins.

ce:section.ce:para: As a greenhouse gas, carbon dioxide was emitted into the atmosphere by burning fossil fuels, which made a great contribution to global warming and extreme weather. Converting CO2 to high value-added chemicals such as carbon monoxide [1,2], methane [3,4], formic acid [5,6], methanol [7,8], olefin [9–11], and liquid fuels has attracted many scientists’ attention.12−13 Upon all these target chemicals, C2–C4 was the higher value and meaning product since the light olefins (C2 =–C4 =) can be used to synthesize more valuable polymers, and the C2–C4 alkanes can be used as the main source of alcohol and light olefins [14–17].

There are several methods for converting CO2 into C2–C4 hydrocarbons, including thermal catalytic hydrogenation, electrocatalysis reduction, and photocatalytic reaction [9,11,18–22]. The low conversion of CO2 and poor selectivity of light olefins indicate that there is still a long way to go for electrocatalysis reduction and photocatalytic reaction [23]. Compared with the above methods, the thermal catalytic reduction of CO2 has many advantages such as higher CO2 conversion and controllable long chain hydrocarbons selectivity [23]. Generally, the reaction route of CO2 hydrogenation to light olefins has the following different mechanisms: (1) Hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol and then methanol to olefins (MTO) [12,24–26]; (2) Hydrogenation of CO2 to CO by Reverse Water Gas Shift (RWGS) reaction and then CO undergoes Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTs) reaction to synthesize hydrocarbons [27,28]. Iron-based catalysts are considered as the most promising materials for industrial application in converting CO2 to C2–C4 compounds due to the abundant reserves and low prices. FeOx can be used as active site for converting CO2 to CO, and FeCx was reported to be the active site for C–C coupling reaction [29–36]. The latter was formed when C atoms occupy the interstices of Fe atoms [31,37,38]. Although many works have been done on Fe-based catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation reduction, there are still many challenges, such as high toxic precursors and long carbonization time. In addition, the reaction mechanism of CO2 hydrogenation on FeCx is still lack of systematic research [31,37].

Although FeOx and FeCx as the active sites for CO2 hydrogenation to olefins have been reported, few research was focused on building FeOx-FeCx heterojunction active sites. In this paper, the synergy effect of support, heterojunction active site, and electronic promoter were considered and applied in the synthesis of mesoscopic catalysts. Herein, a feasible strategy was proposed to synthesize mesoscopic carbon-based iron heterojunction catalysts (Fe3O4-FeCx@N-OMC), which was described in Fig. 1 . Dicyandiamide and phenolic resin were used as nitrogen source and carbon source to assemble N-doped order mesoporous carbon (N-OMC), and the FeCx was formed during the in-situ carbonization process. The synthesis process and reaction mechanism of CO2 hydrogenation were investigated detailedly. This work proposed a simple and feasible synthesis strategy to construct Fe3O4-FeCx heterojunction catalysts, which provided insights on catalysts design and the reaction mechanism of CO2 conversion to light olefins.
The details of materials used in the experiments, characterizations, and CO2 hydrogenation evaluation were listed in supporting information.

Typically, catalysts were prepared using dicyandiamide as N source, F127 as soft template, Fe(NO3)3·9H2O as Fe source, and phenolic resin (M≈500) as C source. Taking 0.2Fe@N-OMC as an example, 2.5 g F127 was added to the mixture of 45 g ethanol and 30 g deionized water, stirring until F127 completely dissolved. Then, 2.5 g dicyandiamide was added to the above solution with stirring to form a clear solution. Subsequently, 0.5 g Fe(NO3)3·9H2O was added with stirring for 1.0 h. Next, 12.5 g phenolic resin ethanol solution (20 wt.% in ethanol) was dropped to the above solution with stirring for 30 min to form a red gel. Then, the gel was evaporated at 50 °C for 6 h and heated at 100 °C for 24 h. The as-formed composites were cut into small pieces for pyrolysis. The pyrolysis was carried out in a tube furnace, the N2 flow rate was 50 mL/min, and the temperature was increased from 30 to 350 °C with the rate of 2 °C/min and kept for 2.0 h, then raised to 600–800 °C with the rate of 1 °C/min and kept for 3.0 h. The obtained black solid was grinded and sieved to 40–60 meshes particles for catalytic evaluation.

0.5 g F127 was first dissolved to the mixture of 20 g ethanol and 10 g deionized water. Then, 0.5 g dicyandiamide was added to the above solution with stirring to form a clear solution. Next, 2.5 g phenolic resin ethanol solution (20 wt.% in ethanol) was dropped to the above solution with stirring for 30 min to form a red gel. Subsequently, the gel was evaporated at 50 °C for 6 h and heated at 100 °C for 24 h. The as-formed composites were cut into small pieces for pyrolysis. The pyrolysis was carried out in a tube furnace, the N2 flow rate was 50 mL/min, and the temperature was increased from 30 to 350 °C with the rate of 2 °C/min and kept for 2.0 h, then raised to 600 °C with the rate of 1 °C/min and kept at 600 °C for 3.0 h.

Taking 0.8Fe-0.1K@N-OMC as an example, 2.5 g F127 was added to the mixture of 45 g ethanol and 30 g deionized water, stirring until F127 completely dissolved. Then, 2.5 g dicyandiamide was added to the above solution with stirring to form a clear solution. Subsequently, 2.0 g Fe(NO3)3·9H2O and 0.25 g KNO3 were added with stirring for 2.0 h. Next, 12.5 g phenolic resin ethanol solution (20 wt.% in ethanol) was dropped to the above solution with stirring for 30 min to form a red gel. Subsequently, the gel was evaporated at 50 °C for 6 h and heated at 100 °C for 24 h. The as-formed composites were cut into small pieces for pyrolysis. The pyrolysis was carried out in a tube furnace, the N2 flow rate was 50 mL/min, and the temperature was increased from 30 to 350 °C with the rate of 2 °C/min and kept for 2.0 h, then raised to 600 °C with the rate of 1 °C/min and kept at 600 °C for 3.0 h. The obtained black solid was grinded and sieved to 40–60 meshes particles for catalytic evaluation. The x and y of xFe-yK@N-OMC mean x g Fe(NO3)3·9H2O and y g KNO3 were added into solution contained 1 g F127.

The supported catalyst 0.8Fe-0.1K/N-OMC was synthesized by impregnation method. First, 0.8 g Fe(NO3)3·9H2O and 0.1 g KNO3 was added into 40 g deionized water, stirring until the crystals completely dissolved. Then, 1.11 g N-OMC (40–60 meshes) was added to the above solution, stirring for 8.0 h. Subsequently, the mixture was evaporated at 100 °C for 8 h and heated at 150 °C for 12 h, and the black solid was obtained. The pyrolysis was carried out in a tube furnace, the N2 flow rate was 50 mL/min, the temperature was increased from 30 to 600 °C with the rate of 1 °C/min and kept at 600 °C for 3.0 h.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Synthesis and structural characterization of Fe3O4-FeCx@N-OMC
ce:section.ce:para: It has been studied systematically that FeCx synthesized by treating Fe2O3 in syngas or methane atmosphere at high temperature, but the preparation of FeCx from Iron-containing inorganic salt directly was rarely reported [34]. Herein, several types of FeCx crystal were formed during the decomposition of Fe(NO3)3·9H2O and carbonization process. The crystal type and structure of as-formed catalysts were characterized by XRD. As shown in Fig. 2 a, the correlation between the types of FeCx and usage of Fe precursor was investigated by XRD, in which the FeCx with different carbon content and Fe3N nanoparticles were formed in all catalysts. Interestingly, the amount of C incorporated in FeCx increased as the increasing Fe precursor. The Fe15.1C crystal was detected in 0.2Fe@N-OMC, while Fe3N and Fe1.88C0.12 crystals were detected in 0.4Fe@N-OMC, and Fe3N and Fe5C2 crystals were detected in 0.6Fe@N-OMC. It can be found that the FeCx with high carbon content were formed when the Fe(NO3)3·9H2O dosage increased over 0.4 g per 1 g F127. In addition, the Fe3N formed in 0.4Fe@N-OMC, which content decreased as the Fe(NO3)3·9H2O dosage increased. Therefore, the incorporation of N and Fe atoms tends to occur in larger Fe crystal, while the incorporation of C and Fe atoms tends to take place in smaller crystal [39]. The broadening of XRD peaks in 0.8Fe@N-OMC implying the particle size of Fe2C, Fe7C3, and Fe5C2 was smaller than the FeCx crystals in other catalysts. The HR-TEM and HAADF-STEM results of 0.2Fe@N-OMC (Fig. S2) and 0.8Fe@N-OMC (Fig. 2) were also consistent with the results of XRD. Sodium chloride (PDF#05-0628) was detected in all catalysts because it was present in the precursor of phenolic resin.

The influence of N source and carbonization temperature on the formation of FeCx had been systematically studied, which was show in Fig. 2b and c. To understand the effect of dicyandiamide, the series of 0.6Fe@N-OMC samples were prepared with different dicyandiamide dosage and characterized by XRD (Fig. 2b). It can be seen that Fe3N did not formed until dicyandiamide was added, and the diffraction peak intensity of Fe3N enhanced as dicyandiamide increased. This trend was contrary to FeCx, implying dicyandiamide promoted the formation of iron nitride instead of iron carbide. Furthermore, the FeNx would transform to FeCx during the FTs reaction, which indicates N source can change the carbonization process of Fe crystal [40,41]. Moreover, the halide ions have been reported to modify the carbonization process of Fe3O4 [42]. On the other hand, the interaction between N and Fe specie may be attributed to the generation of Fe3O4-FeCx heterojunction [42]. Neither diffraction peaks of iron nitride nor iron carbide was appeared in 0.6Fe@N-OMC-N-2.0 for the reason that the specific surface area was decreased, which demonstrated that the large specific surface area favor the generation of FeCx [43]. As shown in Fig. 2c, carbonization temperature also affects the formation of FeCx and Fe3N particles. The FeCx and Fe3N crystal did not formed when the pyrolysis temperature was below 600 °C, the diffraction peak intensity of Fe3N was weakened as the carbonization temperature increased from 600 to 700 °C. Nevertheless, the diffraction peak intensity of FeCx showed the opposite trend, which demonstrates that Fe3N was formed preferentially at low temperature and then transformed to FeCx at high temperature [44]. The XRD result of the reduced 0.8Fe-0.1K@N-OMC was showed in Fig. 2d, where the Fe3O4 (PDF#19-0629) NPs was formed, conforming the Fe3O4-FeCx heterojunction was constructed in 0.8Fe-0.1K@N-OMC that describes in Fig. 1.

As shown in Fig. 3 b, Fe2C, Fe7C3, and Fe5C2 were formed on the mesoporous surface of 0.8Fe@N-OMC. The Fe2O3-FeCx heterojunction nanostructure confined in N-doped graphene shell was further confirmed by HR-TEM. The FeCx crystals were composed by Fe5C2, Fe7C3, and Fe2C, and the lattice spacing of 0.206, 0.208, 0.202, and 0.233 nm corresponding to Fe5C2 (510), Fe2C (101), Fe7C3 (211), and Fe2O3 (112) plane, respectively, and the FeCx crystal was much bigger than Fe2O3 particles [31,39,40]. In Fig. 3c, and d, the lattice spacing of 0.205, 0.244, 0.204, and 0.263 nm corresponding to Fe5C2 (510), Fe2O3 (204), Fe5C2 (510), and Fe2O3 (116) plane. The models of crystal showed in Fig. 3a, c, and d suggest the generation of Fe2O3-FeCx heterojunction. The HAADF-STEM result of 0.8Fe@N-OMC implies the N and O elements were highly dispersed around the FeCx particles (Fig. 3e and f). All the above results indicate that the Fe2O3-FeCx heterojunction confined in N-doped graphene shell was synthesized successfully. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm (Fig. S3a) and HR-TEM images (Fig. S4) showed the N-OMC and xFe@N-OMC have a typical mesoporous structure. The pore size increased with the addition of iron, which may be due to the reaction between the iron and carbon in the inner wall of the mesoporous carbon, thus expanding the channel (Fig. S3b and Table S1). All the above results indicate that the Fe3O4-FeCx heterojunction confined in N-OMC was synthesized successfully.

The FeCx has been used in FTs and CO2 hydrogenation reactions, which showed Fe5C2 and Fe2C could be the active site to reduce CO2 to C2 + hydrocarbon products [36–38]. However, few studies were performed on the Fe3O4-FeCx heterojunction that in-situ confined in porous carbon materials for CO2 hydrogenation. The catalytic activity of Fe3O4-FeCx@N-OMC was investigated in a fixed-bed reactor and the result is shown in Table 1 . It can be found that the blank N-OMC was inactive for hydrogenation of CO2, suggesting that the Fe species were the active sites. The catalytic performance of Fe@N-OMC was variety with the change of Fe loading. The best catalytic performance was obtained on 0.8Fe@N-OMC with the 53.55% CO2 conversion and 5.17% selectivity of CO, and the selectivity of CH4, C2–C4, and C5 + were 12.78%, 86.87%, 0.25%, respectively. As the previous published report, Fe3O4 and FeCx were the active site for RWGS and FTs reactions, respectively [13,31]. Therefore, the difference of catalyst activity may be attributed to the amount of active site (FeOx and FeCx) and the amount of carbon doped in FeCx species. With the increase of Fe loading, the amount of FeOx and FeCx in the catalyst increased, and the conversion of CO2 increased. The FeCx with high carbon content, such as Fe2C and Fe5C2, had high activity for CO2 hydrogenation reaction [45].

The Fe 2p3/2 XPS of 0.2−0.8Fe@N-OMC was performed for determining the FeOx and FeCx content, as shown in Fig. 4 a. The Fe 2p3/2 spectra can be fitted by three peaks that binding energy located at 711.6, 710.3, and 707.0 eV, which was attributed to Fe3+, Fe2+, and FeCx species, respectively [44,46,47]. As shown in Fig. 4a, Fe2+ and FeCx content increased as the increasing Fe loading, but the trend of Fe3+ was opposite, which suggests that Fe3O4 and FeCx increased with the increase of Fe source. The relationship between Fe loading and catalyst activity is shown in Fig. 4b, in which the CO2 conversion raised as the Fe loading increased from 3.1 wt.% to 10.3 wt.%, the selectivity of CO increased strikingly until 5.2 wt.% Fe loading, and then decreased significantly as the Fe loading increased. The result demonstrates that the FTs reaction beginning and accelerating when the Fe loading exceeded 5.2 wt.%. In other words, the FeCx species formed and increased after the Fe loading exceeded 5.2 wt.%, which was consistent with the XPS result. It can be found that the doping of N could increase CO2 conversion and C2–C4 selectivity but suppress the generation of CO and CH4 by comparing catalytic performance of 0.8Fe@N-OMC and 0.8Fe@OMC. The XRD patterns of 0.8Fe@N-OMC and 0.8Fe@OMC (Fig. S5) manifested the FeO and larger FeCx NPs formed in 0.8Fe@OMC compared with 0.8Fe@N-OMC, which disclosing that N doping promoted the formation of FeCx and inhibited crystal agglomeration [40]. Moreover, N doping could enhance the content of surface alkaline site and suppress the absorption and dissociation of H2 that inhibiting the second hydrogenation of light olefins [48].

The CO2-TPD was used to evaluate the CO2 adsorption capacity of the catalyst, and the appropriate chemical adsorption is conducive to the activation of CO2. As shown in Fig. 4c, the CO2 adsorption capacity raised from 0.2Fe@N-OMC to 0.8Fe@N-OMC and then decreased, which may be related to the FeOx content. Therefore, the Fe source transformed to FeCx species more than FeOx will reduce the adsorption capacity of CO2. The desorption temperature decreased before 0.8Fe@N-OMC and then increased, which may be caused by the enlarged FeOx NPs weakening the absorption strength of CO2 [49]. The H2-TPR results are showed in Fig. 4d, in which the peaks at 344 °C and 374 °C were attributed to the reduction of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4 [50]. It was found that the reduction temperatures of 0.2–0.6Fe@N-OMC were higher than those of 0.8–1.2Fe@N-OMC, which may be due to the FeOx size in 0.2–0.6Fe@N-OMC were smaller than those in 0.8–1.2Fe@N-OMC. The CO2-TPD and H2-TPR results indicate that the larger FeOx particles could weaken CO2 adsorption strength and were easily to be reduced [51]. The small FeOx NPs in 0.2–0.6Fe@N-OMC are difficult to be reduced to Fe3O4, which is not the main adsorption site of CO2. The size of FeOx increased with the increase of Fe loading, which makes FeOx easier to be reduced, therefore increased the adsorption capacity but weakened the adsorption strength of CO2 [49]. The FeOx and FeCx content decreased in 1.0Fe@N-OMC and 1.2Fe@N-OMC due to more Fe source transformed to α-Fe. To further confirm the higher content of α-Fe in 1.2Fe@N-OMC, the HR-TEM and line scan (Fig. S6) were performed, in which the FeOx-FeCx nanoparticle was bigger than that in 0.8Fe@N-OMC. Moreover, it can be found that the intensity of C element decreased in the core of nanoparticle, implying the core of this particle was α-Fe rather FeCx or FeOx (Fig. S6c and f). The enlargement of the particles and the decrease of FeOx-FeCx content resulted in a decrease of the catalytic performance of 1.0–1.2Fe@N-OMC, which was consistent with the experimental results shown in Table 1.

ce:section.ce:section-title: The effect of alkali metal (Potassium) on the catalytic activity
ce:section.ce:para: The addition of alkali metal ions could change the surface basicity and weaken the adsorption of H2 molecules, thus reducing the hydrogenation activity [13,28,52]. To investigate the contribution of alkali metal ion (Potassium) to catalytic activity, 0.8Fe-yK@N-OMC (y = 0, 0.05, 0.1, and 0.2) was prepared and the catalytic performance was evaluated. As shown in Fig. 5 a, the conversion of CO2 was maintained at 54% for 0.8Fe-0K@N-OMC and 0.8Fe-0.05K@N-OMC, and then decreased as the K amount increased. Interestingly, 0.8Fe-0.1K@N-OMC had the lowest CH4 selectivity and the highest C2 =–C4 = selectivity. The above results imply that adding K promoter prefer to improve light olefin selectivity and suppress the formation of CH4.

However, the improving catalytic performance is always attribute to the alteration of active sites, which is related to the electronic and structural factors [52]. As shown in Fig. 5b, the XRD was performed for investigating the structural function of K promoter. After the addition of K, the diffraction peaks of Fe5C2 were enhanced and narrowed, which means that the Fe5C2 particles become larger. The K2O species (PDF#27-0431 and 26-1327) were detected in 0.8Fe-0.1K@N-OMC and 0.8Fe-0.2K@N-OMC, which might cover the surface of FeOx and FeCx, thus cutting off the contact of substrate with active site. Moreover, K+ also acts as a catalyst poison for the FTs reaction, resulting in the decrease of catalytic activity of 0.8Fe-0.2K@N-OMC [53]. The CO2-TPD and H2-TPD were carry out to uncover the interaction between the reactant molecule and the active site, which are showed in Fig. 5c and d. It can be found that the CO2 desorption temperature (100 °C) did not change after the adding of K+, but the adsorption capacity (weak chemisorption) was enhanced as the K+ increased, implying the addition of K+ could introduce basic sites or promote the generation of basic sites [11,13,54]. There were two H2 desorption peak in H2-TPD patterns (Fig. 5d), the peaks at 120 °C and 600–700 °C were attributed to the weak and strong desorption on Fe surfaces [55,56]. The decrease of desorption peak indicates that K+ can weaken the chemisorption of hydrogen on iron surface, which can decrease the H* density on the surface of 0.8Fe-yK@N-OMC, thus suppressing the hydrogenation of the CHx* and light olefins [56]. The decreasing capacity of strong desorption also confirmed by the weaken desorption peak of H2. The excessive addition of K+ could cover the surface of Fe species and block the transformation of CO to CH* and CH2*, which might be the reason for poor catalytic activity and higher selectivity of CO, CH4, and less alkanes. The electronic properties of catalytic site were further investigated by XPS. Fig. 5e shows the Fe 2p XPS spectra of 0.8Fe-0.1K@N-OMC and 0.8Fe@N-OMC, in which the 720.09 eV (720.42 eV) and 707.16 eV (707.40 eV) were ascribed to Fe-C of 0.8Fe-0.1K@N-OMC (0.8Fe@N-OMC). The binding energy of Fe-C of 0.8Fe-0.1K@N-OMC shifted to a low value compared with that of 0.8Fe@N-OMC, confirming the increase of charge density on FeCx surface [56]. The K 2p XPS spectra of 0.8Fe-0.05K@N-OMC and 0.8Fe-0.1K@N-OMC are showed in Fig. 5f, in which the binding energy of 0.8Fe-0.1K@N-OMC shifted to a high value after increasing K addition. The hydrocarbon distribution was investigated from 0.8Fe@N-OMC to 0.8Fe-0.1K@N-OMC (Fig. S7a and b). The C1 component was decreased and the light olefins C2 =–C4 = were increased significantly after adding K+, implying the effect of K+ in promoting the selectivity of light olefins. On the basis of the above results, K promoter increasing the electron density and enlarging FeCx NPs size, thus restraining second hydrogenation reaction and CH4 formation.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Effect of reaction conditions and the stability of the 0.8Fe-0.1K@N-OMC
ce:section.ce:para: To investigate the reaction mechanism, different reaction conditions including temperature, pressure, gas hourly space velocity (GHSV), and the ratio of H2/CO2 were explored. As shown in Fig. 6 a, the reaction temperature affected the CO2 conversion and products distribution. The CO2 conversion increased from 31.16% to 66.5% when the reaction temperature increased from 270 °C to 370 °C and then decreased slightly to 64.16% at 420 °C. The CH4 selectivity increased with the increasing temperature while the selectivity of C2–C4 had the opposite trend. The CO selectivity decreased to the bottom at 370 °C and then increased slightly at 420 °C. The content of light olefins reached the highest point at 320 °C and then decreased significantly as the temperature increased to 420 °C. The C5 + selectivity decreased with the temperature increased, implying C5 + species might come from the light olefins. The above results show that high temperature is favor for the dissociation of C–O and hydrogenation reaction, but C–C couple reaction was suppressed due to more CO were converted to CH4 [52].

Fig. 6b shows the effect of reaction pressure on catalytic performance, which reveals that the highest CO2 conversion (54.1%) was achieved at 4.0 MPa. Pressure had little effect on the selectivity of C2–C4, but high pressure would lead to second hydrogenation of light olefins. GHSV affected the CO2 conversion and CO selectivity, high GHSV was accompanied by high CO selectivity and low CO2 conversion, which was attributed to short contact time between CO2 (CO) and active sites. Similarly, high GHSV also suppressed the hydrogenation of light olefins and increased olefins ratio in C2–C4 (Fig. 6d). The ratio of H2/CO2 affected the reaction equilibrium, and the high ratio of H2/CO2 could promote the CO2 conversion and CO transformation to hydrocarbon compounds with more CH4 and C5 + but less C2–C4 products (Fig. 6e). The higher ratio of H2/CO2 promoted the transformation of CO to unsaturated intermediate CHx, which is considered to be the source of C5 +. Therefore, high selectivity of C5 + was obtained under high H2/CO2 ratio [28]. The stability of 0.8Fe-0.1K@N-OMC was investigated under the preferred reaction condition. As shown in Fig. 6c, the conversion of CO2 was 54.5%, the selectivity of CO was 8.9%, the selectivity of CH4, C2–C4, C5 +, and CH3OH were 10.2%, 87.3%, 3.2%, and 0.3%, respectively. The catalytic performance did not change during the 100 h continuous reaction, indicating that the catalyst has excellent stability. The 57Fe Mössbauer spectrum was performed to investigate the Fe species of fresh and spent catalysts, the results are showed in Fig. 6f, Fig. S8, and Tables S3 and S4. We can find that the compositions of χ-Fe5C2 increased from 33.2% to 61.18% after the reaction, and the η-Fe2C and θ-Fe7C3 decreased from 4.6% and 17.6% to 0% and 5.89%, respectively, implying the transformation of η-Fe2C and θ-Fe7C3 to χ-Fe5C2 occurred during the reaction [39]. The Fe0 decreased from 33.9% to 18.2% indicates the oxidation of α-Fe was occurred during the reaction. The high content of χ-Fe5C2 and low content of Fe3O4 were contributed to the excellent catalytic performance of 0.8Fe-0.1K@N-OMC. The XRD patterns of reduced 0.8Fe-0.1K@N-OMC and spent 0.8Fe-0.1K@N-OMC showed in Fig. S9. In which the diffraction peak of FeCx after 100 h reaction did not change, the diffraction peaks Fe3O4 enhanced after reaction for the reason that α-Fe transformed to Fe3O4. The N-doped graphene shell inhibited the sintering and agglomeration of catalyst, blocking the contact between active site and water, which were committed to making the unparalleled stability of this catalyst [39].

ce:section.ce:section-title: The mechanism of Fe3O4-FeCx@N-OMC for converting CO2 to light olefins
ce:section.ce:para:
By analyzing the above results, possible reaction path for 0.8Fe-0.1K@N-OMC is more prefer to be RWGS-FTs route [55]. The Fe3O4 was the active site for RWGS reaction to convert CO2 to CO, and FeCx was the active site for FTs reaction to transform CO to hydrocarbon [28,31]. For tandem reactions, the reaction route determines the selectivity of product. Here in, the relationship between CO2 conversion and product selectivity was explored by changing the GHSV (Fig. 7 a). The CO selectivity was increased and the selectivity of CH4 and C2 + was decreased with the decrease of CO2 conversion. The selectivity of CO and CH4 reached to 95% and 5% as the CO2 conversion falling to 0% approximately in the curve trend (Fig. 7a), indicating it was a RWGS-FTs tandem reaction and CH4 was generated from the direct hydrogenation of CO2 [51]. Additionally, the reaction pathway was also further confirmed by in-situ DRIFTs (Fig. 7b and c). The peaks located at 1250 cm−1 and 1603 cm−1 were attributed to CO2
δ
− originated from chemical adsorption of CO2, and the peak intensity increased with the increasing temperature, which was consistent with the result in Fig. 6a [57]. The peaks at 2112 cm−1 and 2107 cm−1 were assigned to CO species, the peaks at 1474 cm−1 and 1548 cm−1 were attributed to CO3* species, and the HCO3* (1633 cm−1, 1323 cm−1) and HCOO* (1584 cm−1,1394 cm−1) were appeared during the reaction, which proved the RWGS reaction was occurred [51,58]. The peak intensity of HCOO*, HCO3*, and CO3* became weaker as the increase of temperature, which indicates that the increase of temperature is beneficial to the reaction. The peak at 3015 cm−1 was attributed to C–H vibration of CHx, the peaks at 2810–2950 cm−1 were assigned to C–H vibration of HCOO*, and the peaks of 1584 cm−1 and 1394 cm−1 were corresponded the vibration of HCOO*, which was considered to be the key intermediate species of CO2 methanation [59–62]. The peak at 3022 cm−1 corresponding to the C–H vibration of CHO*, which was the crucial species to form CH3OH and CHx, indicating the hydrocarbon and CH3OH were transformed from CO [61]. The CH3 (2975 cm−1), CH2 (3082, 2940, and 1443 cm−1), and CH unsaturated species (3001 and 2904 cm−1) were obvious when the temperature up to 240 °C, which played an important role in C–C bond coupling for generation C2 + hydrocarbons [51,63–65]. The C–H vibration intensity of CHx increased as the increase of reaction temperature, consisting with the result in Fig. 6a. The above results imply that there are two routes for the CO2 hydrogenation in present work: RWGS–FTs reaction and direct CO2 hydrogenation to CH4. Here in, the Fe3O4-FeCx heterojunction structure played a crucial role in connecting the RWGS with FTs reactions ingeniously, which not only reduced the selectivity of CO, but also improved the conversion of CO2 and the yield of C2 + species.

To investigate the importance of the heterojunction structure in the reaction, the 0.8Fe-0.1K/N-OMC was prepared and the catalytic performance was evaluated under the same conditions as 0.8Fe-0.1K@N-OMC. As shown in Fig. S10a, the CO2 conversion decreased significantly to 32.5% compared to 0.8Fe-0.1K@N-OMC (54%), the selectivity of CO increased obviously from 7.9% (0.8Fe-0.1K@N-OMC) to 31.8%, the hydrocarbon distribution except light olefins of 0.8Fe-0.1K/N-OMC did change slightly, and the Cole/C2-C4 decreased from 83% (0.8Fe-0.1K@N-OMC) to 77%. The different catalytic performance demonstrates that the correlation between variety structure of catalyst and catalytic performance. To explore the deep reasons, 0.8Fe-0.1K/N-OMC was investigated by XRD, HR-TEM, and HAADF-STEM (Figs. S10b and S11). The XRD patterns in Fig. S10b showed the formation of Fe5C2 and α-Fe in 0.8Fe-0.1K/N-OMC and the particle size was bigger than that in 0.8Fe-0.1K@N-OMC. The HR-TEM and HAADF-STEM results proved that the Fe5C2 (511) and Fe2O3 (311) crystal planes were formed independently in the 0.8Fe-0.1K/N-OMC instead of Fe2O3-FeCx heterojunction structure (Fig. S11) [34,65]. It also can be found in the results of scan line (Fig. S12a and b) that the peak of C decreased significantly and the peak of O did not alter in the core of particle, implying the core of particle was α-Fe mostly. The above results indicate that the FeOx-FeCx heterojunction structure is critical for converting CO2 to light olefins efficiently. The reaction mechanism was showed in Fig. 7d and e, which shows that CO spillover over FeOx-FeCx heterojunction is better than the diffusion between independent FeOx and FeCx during the RWGS-FTs reaction. It is worth nothing that the synthetic method of N-doped mesoporous carbon confined Fe3O4-FeCx heterojunction in this paper is feasible and efficient. The unique spatial arrangement of FeOx and FeCx, and the N-doped carbon (electron-rich), together with H-deficient surface are contribute to high selectivity of light olefins and low selectivity of C5 + hydrocarbons [66,67]. The N-doped carbon establishes an electron-rich environment, which weakens the adsorption strength of hydrocarbons intermediate and promotes the formation of long-chain products such as C5 +.

In summary, this study investigated the N-OMC confined Fe3O4-FeCx heterojunction materials that employed for CO2 hydrogenation to light olefins. The N-OMC not only has abundant alkaline sites to enhance the adsorption of CO2, but also has complexation with iron ions, which made partial Fe3+ to form FeNx and further converted into FeCx. In addition, the K+ and N atom increase the electron density by transferring electrons to the Fe active center, which inhibits the dissociation and adsorption of H2, therefore increases the selectivity of light olefins. The reaction kinetics and in-situ DRIFTs were performed to study the reaction mechanism, which revealed RWGS–FTs and CO2 directly hydrogenated to CH4 occurred simultaneously on the Fe3O4-FeCx@N-OMC. The Fe3O4-FeCx heterojunction active site combines RWGS and FTs reaction ingeniously, which plays a critical role in improving CO2 conversion and light olefins selectivity, and decreasing CO and CH4 selectivity. The CO was first produced by the RWGS reaction catalyzed by Fe3O4, and then converted to light olefins on the neighboring FeCx active site by FTs reaction. The 0.8Fe-0.1K@N-OMC showed CO2 conversion of 54.5%, C2 =–C4 = selectivity of 65.63%, and a stability of 100 h (3.0 MPa, 320 °C, and GHSV = 4800 mL/gcat/h). The excellent stability of catalyst was attributed to the confinement effect of N-doped graphene shell that inhibiting the sintering of heterojunction active components. This work proposed a simple and feasible synthesis strategy to construct FeOx-FeCx heterojunction catalysts, which provided insights into catalysts design and the reaction mechanism of CO2 conversion to light olefins.
